title: ‘Love, David Cameron': Greensill takes the stand
text:
One job move to start: Law firm Linklaters appointed its first female senior partner in its 183-year history, selecting global corporate head Aedamar Comiskey for the role. Her predecessor, Charlie Jacobs, will leave later this year to become co-head of UK investment banking at JPMorgan Chase.

‘Riding to the rescue with my friend Lex Greensill'

“Mr Greensill, are you a fraudster?”

“No, Ms McDonagh, I am not.” 

That exchange between Lex Greensill and Siobhain McDonagh, a Labour MP, was one of several punchy moments at a UK parliamentary hearing on Tuesday. 

The Treasury select committee spent three hours grilling Greensill, whose eponymous supply chain finance company has collapsed in one of the UK's largest political and financial scandals in years.

Hours before it began, there were huge revelations. 

The UK's Financial Conduct Authority said it was investigating Greensill. 

And the committee disclosed reams of documents showing how former UK prime minister David Cameron lobbied for the company 56 times last spring in an attempt to change the rules around Covid-19 debt schemes.

He was bombarding cabinet ministers and officials via text, WhatsApp, email and phone calls — even in one case promising the Treasury's permanent secretary Sir Tom Scholar that “I will stop annoying you.”

Catch up on the story by DD's Kaye Wiggins and the FT's Jim Pickard here, and dig deeper here. 

The full significance of the hearing will emerge over time — and part two is on Thursday when Cameron will appear before the committee.

Here are some highlights from Tuesday:

  • Conservative MP Harriett Baldwin pressed Greensill on the “conflict of interest” between Greensill Capital and SoftBank. The Japanese group invested in Greensill and also poured money into Credit Suisse funds linked to it, which in turn made bets on Vision Fund companies.

  • Greensill responded that the conflicts could be managed, but Baldwin said it didn't pass the “smell test”.

  • Labour's Angela Eagle cited the FT's coverage of Greensill's loans to Sanjeev Gupta's company on the basis of invoices that have raised suspicions of fraud: “At no point would we or my firm have engaged in financing receivables which we knew to be fraudulent,” Greensill said.

  • In response to more of Eagle's questions, Greensill said Cameron was on the payroll at Greensill as an employee and had a “standing invitation” to board meetings. He confirmed they had travelled on the company's private jet together.

  • Greensill said he hadn't heard of “prospective receivables” and he read about it in the FT. However, a lawsuit against his company from Bluestone Resources said the term was used in its written agreement with Greensill in 2018. And Sanjeev Gupta wrote to the FT using the phrase to describe his companies' financing arrangements with Greensill.

  • Greensill declined to answer questions from Labour MP Emma Hardy about whether the FCA investigated his company in 2018 when it looked into issues linked to the Swiss asset manager GAM, which invested heavily in Greensill products and was forced to liquidate funds. He said he was not sure whether he was allowed to discuss the matter. 

Oh, and there's one more detail we couldn't leave out. In a message to the Treasury's Scholar in March 2020, as the world battled an escalating pandemic, Cameron described his new role like this:

“I am riding to the rescue with supply chain finance with my friend Lex Greensill — my new job,” he wrote, promising an “elbow bump” soon.  

Signed: “Love Dc”

Cathie's Ark sets sail for frothy markets

Before last year Cathie Wood was probably best known for being a Tesla bull.

Wood, a devout Christian who named her asset manager Ark Invest after the gold-covered chest described in the Book of Exodus, predicted in 2018 that shares in Elon Musk's electric car company would soar to $4,000 by 2023.  

Tesla is the biggest holding in Wood's largest exchange-traded fund, the actively managed “Ark Innovation”. Her faith in the company paid off last year, as shares in Tesla rose 700 per cent.

The success of Tesla and other technology stocks Ark owns during the pandemic have catapulted Wood to fame and made her the face of a speculative tech boom that has been compared to the dotcom bubble of the early 2000s. 

With the combined value of the five ETFs Wood manages soaring as high as $60bn, from just $3bn a year ago, it has become difficult to ignore her presence in market discourse. 

One of the key figures behind some of those funds is a familiar face to DD readers, Archegos Capital Management founder Bill Hwang. The embattled investor helped Wood get her start in 2014 when he provided the seed for her first four ETFs.

Hwang and Wood have a lot in common: they're both devoted to a higher power, they like to make bold bets and they have an appetite for risk.

Ark, which is famous for its concentrated bets, is now seeing some of those risky investments begin to fall out of favour amid a broader pullback from tech stocks.

Wood's flagship $21bn Ark Innovation fund has fallen to its lowest level since November after surging almost 150 per cent last year, with some of its biggest holdings down a tenth or more already this month. 

It has now lost over one-third of its value since a February peak, as its heavily weighted tech holdings, including Tesla, Teladoc, Roku and Square have tumbled in recent weeks.

Ark's bullish investment strategy has charged ahead despite these losses, selling big-name tech positions like Apple while doubling down on smaller companies, regardless of their performance.

One example is the commercial electric vehicle company Workhorse Group, whose lacklustre first-quarter earnings on Monday were further bruised after losing out on a $6bn deal with the US Postal Service to rival vehicle maker Oshkosh. 

Yet, Ark has continued to increase its stake in the group.

For Wood, it's no big deal. “I love the set-up” she told CNBC last week, assured that her big bets would pay off in time. 

For more on Ark, Alphaville's Jamie Powell offers his takes here and here.

Amazon versus Walmart: clash of the retail titans

The world's most feared retailers, Amazon and Walmart, have sunk billions into their respective ecommerce arsenals. 

But the battle has entered new turf — somewhere Amazon has worked since its inception to disrupt — as “the everything store” encroaches on the one territory where Walmart has always managed to beat Jeff Bezos: brick-and-mortar storefronts.

The first Amazon Fresh supermarket, which opened last September in Los Angeles, is a symbol of the online retail group's ambitions to gain a real foothold in the $1.3tn grocery market (without forgetting that Amazon acquired high-end Whole Foods for $13.4bn in 2017). 

It's also a swift retaliation against its largest competitor, as Walmart invests record sums into building its online presence.

This being said, Walmart is still very much a digital underdog. Amazon retains 40 per cent of the US ecommerce market, next to its own 7 per cent.

In other words, the battle for its grocery aisles is one Walmart can't afford to lose.

Job moves

  • Glenn Youngkin, former co-chief executive of the Carlyle Group, has won the Republican nomination for Virginia governor.

  • J David Enriquez, head of private equity at the $251bn New York City Retirement Systems, has left the pension fund to join Rothschild & Co's US private equity division, Five Arrows Capital Partners, as a member of its multi-strategies team.

  • Deutsche Bank has hired Richard Robinson as a managing director and vice-chair of global industrials. He joins in New York after serving as co-head of basic materials investment banking for the Americas at Morgan Stanley.

  • Clifford Chance has hired a trio of private equity lawyers from Kirkland & Ellis in Munich. The hires include Volkmar Bruckner and Mark Aschenbrenner at the partner level.

  • Kirkland & Ellis has hired Gregory Scott, a private equity senior associate at Clifford Chance, as a partner in its London office, according to Financial News. The firm also added Stanley Ramsay as a tax partner. He joins the New York office from Weil, Gotshal & Manges.
